Author: Gateway#3763

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <J Oliver Westbrook> i think you need to wipe your db and chain data and get the bootstrap again

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <J Oliver Westbrook> so go in your /opt folder and for each coin folder in there, go in, go into the all caps folder within, delete everything EXCEPT FOR YOUR wallet file. Your wallet file is named something like ‚Äúvrsc_store.dat‚Äù

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <J Oliver Westbrook> then from within that same folder download the bootstrap for that chain, unpack it, after unpacking delete the tar file, then start the chain

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <J Oliver Westbrook> my guess is when you ran out of space your db or block data got corrupted

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <J Oliver Westbrook> let me know if you‚Äôd like me to fix for you, i‚Äôm happy to do so, you‚Äôll just have to give me ssh access

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Draeth> that worked! you rock!

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <J Oliver Westbrook> Woop!

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Draeth> So, long story short, I was still having space issues (I need to look into what is taking up space that shouldn't be there). I ended up creating a new volume with enough space to hold the kmd bootstrap, moving the kmd bootstrap there, then unpacking it into the correct directory

Author: Gateway#3763

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <zpajk> At what block? Or the transaction id? Don't want to type each character from an image.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <superbig> 0c35637a0e8153fd947f830c7ccc5d1fbf1b3f5517f3ca0ceaf13edddcc3857d

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <zpajk> Thanks.
<https://explorer.vrsc.0x03.services/address/R9g49XDc9gqvi5dkeEGJBenrtAWJ6MT7fz>
So it's on the explorer, so it's just not only your wallet messing up.
You haven't sent the transaction yourself, which indicates that someone else has access to your address and/or wallet.
And seeing how it's sent to a private address there is no way of tracing it, but even if it was possible there's not much to do about it.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <superbig> Are you sure it was stolen?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <zpajk> It was sent out from your wallet, by someone other than you, to an external address. So unless you've forgotten about sending it to a service handling private z-addresses (like CryptoBridge) then they're most likely transferred by someone other than you to their own address.
Has anyone had access to your computer handling the wallet? Backups of the wallet.dat? WIF keys? Are any of those stored on an online services where your login credentials may be compromised, like e-mail auth? Are there any file sharing services running on the device you've got copies of the wallet on that could have been hacked?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <superbig> The wallet papers were never passed on to anyone else.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <zpajk> And of course the risk of malware getting installed, stealing files like crypto wallets.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <superbig> The machine is a new system. Kill with anti-virus software, no poison

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <zpajk> Seeing how you've been staking the amount you're running a native wallet which uses an wallet.dat file located on that device. If that has been stolen then they've got access to every address.

Brand new system? Cheap shady device with preinstalled OS from the internet or from a respectable retailer?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Thoskk> guess a pwd for sending would really not be a bad idea.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <zpajk> Except wallet.dat is still unencrypted.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Thoskk> right

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <zpajk> Which it needs to be to stake.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Thoskk> so the pwd had to be stored elswehere, in an encrypted way

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <zpajk> Else paper wallet with BIP38 is reasonable.(The address becomes encrypted with password, and needs to be decrypted with it to use.)

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <zpajk> Don't get me wrong, @superbig, I feel really bad if that's the case, but I'm only trying to state the vulnerabilities and what could have happend. I hope you the best!
I'm off to rake some leaves.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <GlorymanRTS> @zpajk omg u can get ur wallet stolen by buying 2nd hand pc!

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <GlorymanRTS> I wish there was some kind of list of ways to secure crypto wallets. So, computer noobs like me can protect ourselves.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <Thoskk> @GlorymanRTS  Well, if you buy a cheap PC from the internet, with pre-installed OS, the **very least** thing to do is: Make a fresh install of the OS (you should have the key if it's Windows), get a firewall and antivirus of your own choice, choose a safe password and don't login as administrator or user with high privileges.
But it's probably better not to buy a cheap/used machine if you aren't sure how to take care of. You wouldn't buy a used and probably modded car if you wouldn't know more or less exactly that it's ok and compliant to regulations... could also cost you a lot on top.

Author: Gateway#3763
